children.subject: Just my 2 cents but those are 3 pretty time-consuming classes. 170’s psets aren’t abysmally long but the content can be pretty tough to master. 188 workload from what I know isn’t the worst but again psets + projects (smaller than lost upper div ones). 189 has from what I know The Long Psets™️ along with several coding portions (which aren’t the time consuming parts). Assuming you take no other classes and do nothing else you might be able to get by but I would personally not recommend that unless you have a good record with understanding the concepts and doing psets speedy fast.

<md>If Sahai is teaching in the fall then you're probably gonna struggle with how long his psets are. He also seems to put soft prereqs on 127 and 126. If 188 and 170 were both light classes then I'd say this is doable. Unless you're already used to the workload of 4 relatively nontrivial techs then I wouldn't approach this schedule</md>

history.content: no youll be fine, i and others have planned to do that. just don't expect to do research and an internship/a lot of clubs alongside that.

children.subject:
Thanks for replying and taking a look at my circumstances.

O.K.

Let's see how things can stack up.

For 61A , 61B, I have both A+'s

For Math 53, 54 I have both A+'s.

CS 70 (taking this semester / hoping for at least A-)

Stat 134 (taking this semester / something I use for my EMS major requirement, but should supplement CS 70).

Research experience: currently in scientific computing in Dept. of Astro. (Though not ML, still teaches me essential research skills and sharpens my Python)

Question: Does self studying machine learning from a book (e.g. Hands-On Machine Learning with Scikit-Learn, Keras, and TensorFlow) help in the CS 188 and CS 189 courses?

One thing that has put me at disadvantage was choosing the EECS path a bit late in my career, but I hope that I can make it through.

I wouldn't be able to answer that question for you.

I haven't taken 188 and 189.

I would recommend emailing the instructor or your academic advisor.
Fair enough. I suppose my professors know more than I do regarding this.

Please take Tony's advice with a grain of salt, since spring 189 is VERY DIFFERENT than fall 189. I believe the instructors say is from Fall 2020. Fall 189 is very heavily influenced by Professor Sahai, and has eecs 126/127 as unofficial prereqs and is a very heavy workload https://www.eecs189.org. I would definitely recommend having those classes as a background. Spring 189, specifically 189 with Professor Shewchuk, is very much a normal CS upper div, and like all other cs upper divs, only relies on lower divs as official and unofficial prerequisites. As in you, and many others, can succeed in that class, and learn lots of cool ML stuff (though the math doesn't go quite as deep/intense as a sahai style 189) https://people.eecs.berkeley.edu/~jrs/189/ here you can see the prereqs are:

  • Math 53 (or another vector calculus course),
  • Math 54, Math 110, or EE 16A+16B (or another linear algebra course),
  • CS 70, EECS 126, or Stat 134 (or another probability course).
  • Enough programming experience to be able to debug complicated programs without much help. (Unlike in a lower-division programming course, the Teaching Assistants are under no obligation to look at your code.)

Don't take my word for it, take professor shewchuks: @8773_f3 "Don't worry about what courses you've taken; worry about what you understand."


The hardest math in 189 is hw2 https://people.eecs.berkeley.edu/~jrs/189/hw/hw2.pdf

If you think you can solve that, maybe working with friends and/or reviewing the helpful prereq links on the website, with help from course piazza/office hours then I say go for 189!
Thanks Alex! I learned something from this :D

Any time Tony :) and sadly Ryota I don't have any insights for Summer 189. I would recommend emailing the instructors and asking (usually grad/undergrad students teach summer cs courses) once that is announced.

Ryota,

From reading quite a couple of your previous posts, I'm inferring that you're looking to get involved in research ASAP and that is a big reason why you're contemplating your current course load of 188,189,170. 

I was actually planning on taking CS189 Sp21, but I've decide to move that course back and take it after I've taken 127/126. Heard that a lot of people from Fa20 had to PNP. That's why the instructor asked the EECS advisors to send out the attached message. Hope the attached message helps.

Tony (from GBO)

IF YOU'RE PLANNING TO TAKE CS 189 READ THIS
 
Instructors say:
  • The stated prereqs for the course ( MATH 53 and MATH 54; and COMPSCI 70) are *definitely* not sufficient to succeed in CS 189.
  • You must know how to program a computer
  • Students need more continuous probability of the type that is taught in EECS 126, Stat 140, or Stat 134.
  • You need to be familiar with ideas around continuous optimization. Just MATH 53 is not enough. The solid preparation in vector calculus that is taught in EECS 127 is best here.  Taking CS 189 after EECS 127 helps students in 189 focus on machine learning, instead of getting lost in the optimization.
  • The EECS honor society Eta Kappa Nu (HKN) has put together a map that is far better in terms of telling students what background they need than anything else:
    https://hkn.eecs.berkeley.edu/assets/course-map-2019-da79ecbe2fc25e6b6349b8931364890032b8d51aacaccea65151ae98316f0587.png
Please do not take CS 189 if you are academically underprepared.

history.content:
Dear EECS 101,

For the coming fall, I am considering taking CS 188, CS 189, CS 170 together. Is that a very terrible idea?

Thank You,

Ryota I
history.subject: CS 188 and CS 189 Together
